entry.title: Compiler: Instruction Reordering and need for Fences!

link.title: Compiler: Instruction Reordering and need for Fences!

entry.content:
When you compile a code with a compiler like GNU C Compiler(gcc), you expect it to generate architecture specific code which can be executed on the specified target machine. But the modern compiler does a whole lot of optimizations which can give better performance out-of-box. And one of the optimization that most compiler does is instruction re-ordering so that it can fill the instruction pipelines more efficiently, ultimately leading to fewer CPU cycle stalls and better throughput.

Demonstration:

We will use gcc here to compile code for x86 architecture and view the difference in assembly. Let’s consider the below code

Let’s see the pre-assembly code it generates with Level-2 optimization using command:

gcc foo.c -S -masm=intel -O2; cat foo.s

Note: As one can see the below snippet of assembly attracts my attention which doesn’t match our :

mov DWORD PTR foob[rip], 0
add eax, 1
mov DWORD PTR fooa[rip], eax

The instructions are placed such that foob is set to 0 first and then fooa to +1 to that. This demonstrates that the instruction being re-ordered during compilation.

Memory barrier in gcc

Well now try with gcc foo.c -S -masm=intel -O2 -Dmbarrier; cat foo.s and see the result of pre-assembly. Surprised!!! And the instructions are prohibited from re-ordering even before assembling out.

Note: gcc is smart compiler and so it will be difficult to find this problem in final assembly generated. To verify, compile the code with gcc foo.c -O2 -g followed by objdump -dS a.out | less to see the final generated assembly code. Once can see the instructions getting re-ordered there as well but task dependencies are resolved.

Out of order Execution

Modern processors use technique called Out-of-order execution to optimize the workload performance. I will explain it in brief here.

Just like above instruction re-ordering in compiler, processor can even do re-ordering at its own end too to decrease stalls. Modern architectures supports multiple Functional Units in a core capable of performing separate operations like Load, store, integer, floating arithmetics, branch predictions, etc. When instructions is fetched and decoded, it is pushed to the instruction queue of a core from where it will get respective functional unit if available. To increase performance, the processor can re-order at this point and push certain instructions earlier to be executed if respective unit is idle.

This leads to other problem like instruction dependencies, such that “what if one instructions drive the result of other? Does the next instructions be re-order before current instruction?”

The solution is just like dependency graph in compiler, find instruction dependency in a tree and allow independent instruction to be re-ordered at execution time in processor. This ensures the single thread execution to be look as if it was executed sequentially only. But what about concurrent programs, those with multiple threads being executed in multiple CPUs simultaneously?

Consider below program where variable A is shared across both threads.

Program executed by Thread0:

A = 1;
A = 2;

Program executed by Thread1:

Possible values that Thread1 reads could be {B1=0, B2=0},{B1=1, B2=1},{B1=1, B2=2},{B1=2, B2=2}. So you might think that if condition will never be satisfied.

Well you are right, but I will show you that it can if processor does re-ordering such that B2 = A gets executed before B1 = A, though not with gcc.

Demonstration using JVM

The x86 has strong memory model to sort out such problems and so demonstrating such concept on x86 is difficult. Hence we will take help of JAVA which uses Hotspot JIT to execute code on JVM.

Consider below Java code

The above program sets three values and reads in reverse order to increase effect of instruction re-ordering. The program indicates possible values of three variable in comments.

Note: The result may vary system to system and even across multiple runs. I got several prints when using openjdk-1.8.

Ideally, nothing should get printed on the screen, but if you also got the print, then your JVM also re-ordered instructions during execution. Once can find out using JVM printAssembly with

java -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+PrintAssembly -XX:PrintAssemblyOptions=intel foo
If you face problems related to hsdis shared object then you may have to manually build one. Or download one for x86 from here. Use command LD_LIBRARY_PATH=<path-to-hsdis-amd64.so> java -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+PrintAssembly -XX:PrintAssemblyOptions=intel foo

This gave me long output from which I extracted important part:

0x00007f816918c1c4: mov    DWORD PTR [r10+0x14],0x2  ;*putfield c
; - App::lambda$main$0@17 (line 16)
; - App$$Lambda$1/471910020::run@4 
; - java.lang.Thread::run@-1 (line 747)
; implicit exception: dispatches to 0x00007f816918c26d 
0x00007f816918c1cc: mov    DWORD PTR [r10+0xc],0x1  ;*putfield a 
; - App::lambda$main$0@2 (line 12) 
; - App$$Lambda$1/471910020::run@4 
; - java.lang.Thread::run@-1 (line 747)

0x00007f816918c1d4: mov    DWORD PTR [r10+0x10],0x1  ;*synchronization entry 
; - java.lang.Thread::run@-1 (line 747)

As seen from above, JIT tries to set var c=2 first followed by a=1 and b=1 which is clear indication of re-ordering. Similarly one can see at many places in assembly where instructions are being re-ordered. Since we are using JAVA language which uses Hotspot Just In Time (JIT) compiler, The instructions in assembly are in the order of execution and hence we see the BUG!!! getting printed on.

Fences

The compilers like GNU C and other well known compiler uses inbuilt memory fences. Since they are compilers and produces binary that gets executed on the system, it is platform architecture’s duty to provide barriers to stop such re-ordering( which x86, SPARC, PowerPC and all major does).

This makes almost every CPU architecture, compilers (like Go, GNU C, Java, etc.) and even Linux kernel to define their own memory model to provide a way to synchronize data across whole system. It is very long topic and very much evolved topic to be discussed later on.

entry.title: Pthread locks: Mutex vs Spilocks vs Futex!

link.title: Pthread locks: Mutex vs Spilocks vs Futex!

entry.content:
Locking

During multi-threading or multi-processing, the biggest challenge is selecting types of locks. When writing C code, one can manually write their own locking mechanism or can use glibc wrappers for Mutex and spinlocks.

Mutex vs Spinlocks

Mutex are low overhead locking mechanism with the concept of sleeping the process when waiting for the lock. The mutex implements sleeping mechanism and relinquishes the CPU during that period. This gives way for other tasks to use that CPU.

The drawback is that there can be cases when lock is available and the mutex is sleeping which may leave out the opportunity. Hence, this is used when critical section is large or there are lots of processes in CPU where allowing other threads can effectively increase throughput of the system.

Unlike mutex, spinlocks differs in the manner of waiting for the lock. It constantly does busy-waiting over the lock without relinquishing the CPU. This is useful when critical section size is relatively small and/or with less processes in the system.

Futex

Futex is userspace optimization of the mutex.

Basically, mutex makes a _syscall to the system where kernel handles all the locking, thus leaving the userspace. This can be useful when userspace don;t want overhead of maintaining the locking mechanisms as it has to do book-keeping.

To solve those, linux kernel implements futex which tries to remain in the user-space for shorter time and acquires lock if available. It though goes to kernel space after specific threshold, it benefits those small critical sections where going to kernel and coming back is latency intensive.

The futex is advantageous for kernel code like drivers and kernel modules which makes lots of _syscall.

Programic view

or Github

Analysis of Locking in C: Mutex vs Spinlocks vs Futex

The program pthread_locks.c contains code with the implementation of all the three locking mechanisms. Once can get specific code for a lock with -E parameter to gcc. e.g. to get pre-processed code for Spinlocks only: gcc pthread_locks.c -lpthread -DUSE_SPINLOCK -DLOOPS=100000000 -E | less

The program is intended for 2 parallel threads trying to complete LOOPS.

How to compile

  • For use with Mutex: gcc pthread_locks.c -lpthread -DLOOPS=100000000 -o mutex
  • For use with SPIN_LOCK: gcc pthread_locks.c -lpthread -DUSE_SPINLOCK -DLOOPS=100000000 -o spinlock
  • For use with FUTEX: gcc pthread_locks.c -lpthread -DUSE_FUTEX -DLOOPS=100000000 -o futex

Analysis

My system info with lscpu command:

We will use perf tool to analyse the workload performance.

  • With Mutex

  • With Spinlock

  • With Futex

Use perf tool to find the CPUs utilized to find the difference in all three mechanism.

  • Futex will consume least CPU and Spinlock/Mutex the most.
  • Instructions per Cycles will be more in Futex, though the time taken by futex will be more.
  • Futex are user space optimization of mutexs and tries to make least syscalls leading to increase in IPC, but since it gets less cycles the time taken will be more.

Add-ons:

  • Use htop in other terminal to view the difference in CPU utilization for each execution.
  • Do objdump -dS a.out on binary generated to see the changes in instructions. Compile with -g in gcc to get more debug info for binary with objdump
entry.summary: Locking During multi-threading or multi-processing, the biggest challenge is selecting types of locks. When writing C code, one can manually write their own locking mechanism or can use glibc wrappers for Mutex and spinlocks.

    • Booting debian os on omap4 board
    • kernel compilation

    • stream triad : For L1,L2 and LLC cache size
    • stress-ng : Swiss knife of many benchmarks

    • rt-app : Configurable AOSP based workload generator
    • redis : In-memory single thread database benchmark
    • YCSB : PLugin based database benchmarking system
    • SPEC : int and float based benchmark suite(2006 and 2017 versions)
    • schbench and hackbench : scheduler wakeup latency benchmarking
  21. Lock Optimization

    • [Intel specific] (https://github.com/parthsl/tools/tree/master/RAPL_Energy_measurement){:target=”_blank”}

entry.title: Building Custom Linux Kernel!
entry.content:
Linux kernel is a nice piece of collaborative work developed by thousands of developers across the world. Hence it always feels proud to get our hands dirty with such art.

This post gives a begineer’s guide to how to compile the kernel in your system for the first time and install it.

Get the kernel sources

git clone https://www.github.com/torvalds/linux.git

Build the dependencies

Install packages for compiler, curses, flex, bison, etc based on your linux distro

  • For dnf/yum based distro 
    sudo dnf install bison automake autoconf flex ncurses-devel elfutils-libelf-devel make gcc elfutils-devel libunwind-devel xz-devel numactl-devel openssl-devel binutils-devel
  • For apt based distro 
    sudo apt install flex libncurses5 elfutils openssl libssl-dev automake bison pkg-config libncurses5-dev

Configure kernel

Generally linux kernel has thousands of parameters and modules to be configured based on the system architecture.

Linux kernel maintains .config file in root folder of kernel source tree. One can use any editor to configure the file but the curses based builtin tool makes it easy to change any configurations.

For begginer’s one can get default config file for x86_64 platform by below command, while for other architectures like PowerPC,MIPS,arm64,etc. look thorugh arch/<architecture name>/configs/ folder to find proper name.

make x86_64_defconfig

To traverse through the config file, just use make menuconfig command to fire up curses based window for easier navigation.

Compile kernel

Compiling of kernel goes through compilation of several files which may take time in several minutes to hours in typical desktop systems. The make with -j<nr_threads> arguments helps out here by parallel building. nproc total CPUs in the system here.

make -j`nproc`

Once compiled succesfully, the output is a vmlinux file in the root directory which is basically the kernel.

Installing kernel

  • Kernel built vmlinux is the file which gets executed firstly after system boot, hence it cannot depend on any other code or library as it itself has the loader and linker. For this reason, the vmlinux file is statically build. The kernel installation gets done in three parts: installation of vmlinux, kernel modules and initrd image.

  • The vmlinux needs to copied at /boot partition along with its System.map and .config file as optional things.

  • The vmlinux contains module codes, which means it has capability to add some code to itself after it gets executed. This modules are basically drivers, energy governors, etc. which needs to be added along ith the kernel. This can be invoked by make modules_install which will compile relevant modules configured using .config file and install it to /lib/modules/ directory.

  • The system boot sequence is as follows:
    1. The power on button invokes the system firmware/BIOS which in turn powers on motherboard components including disks.
    2. The control is then passed on to the boot loader like GRUB/LILO seating in /boot partition of the disk. It is the one which provides options to select a kernel to be loaded.
    3. The boot loader then invokes the initrd image which does mounting of several disk paritions like /root, /home/, /swap, etc. and boots vmlinux from there in. The initrd thus has to be generated using mkinitrd command and boot loader has to be updated for the new kernel addition.
  • The Makefile does all the above three steps and updates the boot loader using below command 
    sudo make install
  • Manual method 
    make modules_install -j`nproc`

    Get kernel-version-name from /include/config/kernel.release file.

    mkinitramfs -o initramfs-<kernel-version-name>.img <kernel-version-name>
cp initramfs--<kernel-version-name>.img /boot
cp .config /boot/config--<kernel-version-name>
cp System.map /boot/System.map--<kernel-version-name>
cp vmlinux /boot/vmlinuz--<kernel-version-name>

Booting new kernel

  • If succesfully installed the new kernel, then one can reboot the system and find the kernel with its version installed in boot loader. Just select that kernel to start the system with your new kernel. After system start one can use uname -a to find the current kernel info.
  • Other way to start the new kernel is to build custom initrd from above manual steps and invoke below command 
    kexec ./vmlinux "./initrd.img" --append="`cat /proc/cmdline`"

    The advantage of above kexec command is that it will load the new kernel without rebooting the system. Also even with just modul installation step only one can test this kernel without updating boot loader or /boot partition.
entry.summary: Linux kernel is a nice piece of collaborative work developed by thousands of developers across the world. Hence it always feels proud to get our hands dirty with such art.
